thread.title: 27 Music Facts You May Not Have Known About Some Of Your Favorite Pop Stars
thread.title_full: 27 Music Facts You May Not Have Known About Some Of Your Favorite Pop Stars

author: Michael Blackmon
title: 27 Music Facts You May Not Have Known About Some Of Your Favorite Pop Stars
text:
View this image ›
Ian Gavan / Getty Images ID: 10597889 2. TLC was the first girl group to nab a diamond album , with CrazySexyCool selling more than 10 million units. This solidified them as one of the best-selling girl groups of all time. View this image ›
Jeff Haynes / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10597930 3. Aretha Franklin’s “Respect” is actually a cover , though the Queen of Soul definitely popularized the iconic song. View this image ›
Express Newspapers / Getty Images The original recording was written by Otis Redding.
ID: 10597761 4. Outkast replaced themselves at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 when their single “Hey Ya!” usurped “The Way You Move” in 2004. View this image ›
Scott Gries / Getty Images ID: 10597831 5. Ashanti holds the Guinness World Record for the highest first-week sales for a debut female artist, thanks to her self-titled album, Ashanti , with 503,000 copies sold in its first week. View this image ›
Jason Merritt / Getty Images ID: 10597766 6. Loretta Devine was in the original Broadway production of Dreamgirls in the role of Lorrell Robinson. She also played the jazz singer in the 2006 film. View this image ›
John Ricard / Getty Images ID: 10597767 7. Mariah Carey and Boyz II Men have held the record since 1995 for the song — “One Sweet Day” — with the most weeks at number one on the Billboard Hot 100. Dan Groshong / AFP / Getty Images
Diane Freed / Getty Images
 The song spent 16 weeks atop the Hot 100.
ID: 10605713 8. The “romantic woes” of Kandi Burris led to her writing the Grammy-winning TLC song “No Scrubs” along with her former Xscape group member Tameka “Tiny” Harris. Craig Barritt / Getty Images
Prince Williams / Getty Images
 ID: 10606009 9. Janet Jackson’s “You Want This” features a sample of The Supremes’ “Love Child.” Archive Photos / Getty Images
Brenda Chase / Getty Images
 ID: 10605845 10. Whitney Houston’s “I Will Always Love You” was originally written and recorded by Dolly Parton, though Houston’s version is usually assumed to be the one true rendition. View this image ›
Vince Bucci / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10597776 11. Keri Hilson wrote “Break the Ice,” one of the songs from Britney Spears’ comeback album, Blackout . View this image ›
Jason Merritt / Getty Images ID: 10597772 12. Whitney Houston had a seven consecutive singles hit number one on the Billboard Hot 100 from 1985 to 1988, a feat that still stands today. View this image ›
Bertrand Guay / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10597853 13. Lauryn Hill is the first woman to win five Grammys in one night. View this image ›
Vince Bucci / AFP / Getty Images At the time, Hill’s achievement was a huge feat for women in music. Beyoncé and Adele both later broke that record.
ID: 10597780 14. Sevyn Streeter wrote Ariana Grande’s hit song “The Way.” View this image ›
Alberto E. Rodriguez / Getty Images ID: 10597771 15. LaWanda Page, who played the role of Aunt Esther on Sanford and Son , is the speaking voice heard at the beginning of Rupaul’s classic hit “Supermodel (You Better Work).” Alberto E. Rodriguez / Getty Images
NBC / Getty Images
 ID: 10607165 16. Blue Ivy Carter became the youngest person to chart on Billboard in 2012 when her father, Jay Z, released “Glory” not too long after she was born. Loading View on Instagram
instagram.com ID: 10597781 17. Brandy Norwood was the first black singer to become the face of Covergirl and her legendary voice was praised by John Frusciante, former guitar player for the Red Hot Chili Peppers who said he loved her “phrasing” and “rhythm.” View this image ›
Angela Weiss / Getty Images ID: 10597787 18. Diana Ross is a twelve time Grammy nominee , though she never won one. She does, however, have a Lifetime Achievement Grammy. View this image ›
Evening Standard / Getty Images This includes the nominations Ross received while she was lead singer of The Supremes.
ID: 10597788 19. Rihanna is the artist with the third most number-one hits on the Billboard Hot 100. View this image ›
Jason Merritt / Getty Images Only Mariah Carey and The Beatles have more.
ID: 10597792 20. Michael Jackson was the first artist to have a single debut at number one on the Hot 100 with “You Are Not Alone.” View this image ›
Don Emmert / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10597801 21. Gladys Knight persuaded Berry Gordy, the founder of Motown, to sign The Jackson Five. View this image ›
Mike Coppola / Getty Images Though it’s always been believed that Diana Ross discovered the group.
ID: 10597810 22. Beyoncé’s groundbreaking album, Lemonade , is the first and only album to have 12 singles on the Hot 100 simultaneously. View this image ›
Handout / Getty Images ID: 10597857 23. Tupac completed his 12-track album, The Don Killuminati: The 7 Day Theory , which included, writing, recording, and mixing in seven days. View this image ›
Wikipedia Commons / Via en.wikipedia.org ID: 10597863 24. Merry Clayton’s stunning vocals on the Rolling Stones song “Gimme Shelter” were recorded during a late-night session and were a last-minute decision. View this image ›
Larry Busacca / Getty Images Clayton discussed the recording of the song in the Academy Award-winning documentary Five Feet From Stardom.
ID: 10597895 25. Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson were the writing duo behind some of Motown’s biggest hits such as “You’re All I Need To Get By” and “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough.” View this image ›
Stephen Lovekin / Getty Images ID: 10597908 26. Though Lil Kim was well established in the music industry prior to the ensemble single “Lady Marmalade,” the collaboration helped the rapper notch her first and only number-one on the Hot 100. View this image ›
Brenda Chase / Getty Images ID: 10598006 27. Jidenna, the man behind the hit “Classic Man,” appeared on Season 1 of Issa Rae’s HBO show Insecure , but the two have a long history as friends. Alex Wong / Getty Images
Frederick M. Brown / Getty Images
 The two have been friends since they were students at Stanford University.
ID: 10607145 Happy Black History Month! View this image ›
BET / Via giphy.com ID: 10607973 Check out more articles on BuzzFeed.com!
